The first Mirror's Edge, that came out around 9 years ago, was a simple experimental game by developer DICE, to see how a first-person parkour game could be handled. It was a decent game, but didn't have nearly enough content to be a great game. However, some years later, DICE has returned to try to make a sequel to the first underwhelming game, powering it on the amazing new Frostbite 3 engine, that powered BF4 and Star Wars Battlefront. First off, just like most DICE titles these days, the graphics are really impressive. And the parkour mechanics are just as good, if not better than they were in the original Mirror's Edge. But, for some reason, DICE removed the ability to disarm guards, which makes combat a lot harder. Also, the story is even more bland than the original, and is pretty short too. Not to mention the barren and boring open-world. This game is not worth the money. Sorry for the short review. My heart was just not in this.

The amount of times I died because of a bug or Faith being stupid and jumping off buildings instead of running on walls is massive... title: Mitsurugi Kamui Hikae
summary: Mitsurugi Kamui Hikae is the story of a demonic sword, and the young warrior who stole it for her own ends. Hot on her heels is our main character, and her best friend. Once friends, but now forced to fight each other, players will cut their way through arenas filled with monsters, robots, and thugs in need of a good slicing.
reviews: Lives and dies by its combat. There's nothing else here, and I don't say that to be snarky. There's a story that barely exists (maybe two minutes of total cutscene time), but outside of that, it's all action. Thankfully, 'Mitsurugi' overcomes the low budget to deliver excellent mechanics that are capable of standing entirely on their own. I wish there was a little more to it all.

Mitsurugi Kamui Hikae is a prime example of a title that lives and dies by how entertaining its gameplay is. Fortunately, the stylish hack and slashing that's on offer here is worth checking out if you're a fan of the genre. Despite its low budget feel, this is a Japanese indie game that delivers on what it sets out to do, and the result is a focused and satisfying release that's perfect for a quick fix of over-the-top action.
This schoolgirl revenge story shows some technical prowess from a small Japanese team. Shame that actually playing it feels like drowning into a pit of tar. [May 2016]
Mitsurugi Kamui Hikae has the potential to be an enjoyable title if you learn to master its combat system, making use of all the moves on offer.
If hack and slashes are your thing, then go for it. But for those on the fence, I’d say purchase the latest Devil May Cry game and go wild.
It’s good, but not great. Download with caution.

Mitsurugi Kamui Hikae is an arena fighter that features a great combo system that makes it fun to play... for a while. Unfortunately it has a limited number of enemy combatants, and once you learn the strategies for beating them, the gameplay quickly becomes repetitive.

In fact, it’s almost like a tech demo where the development team has come up with a brilliant combat system and has released that as a commercial project in the hope that a publisher will take note and throw them the money they need to make a real game next.

title: MLB 14: The Show
summary: MLB 14 The Show is a realistic baseball game that allows players to feel the MLB experience with moments such as when you're called up to the majors, a sacrifice fly to left field, or crushing a walk-off homer to win it all.
reviews: MLB 14: The Show is a fantastic first offering on a new platform. I am impressed that every single feature is included, and the visuals are truly stunning.

Not much keeps MLB 14 The Show on PS4 from being the very best it can be on almost all levels. Though some uncommon visual and network discrepancies linger, San Diego Studios raises the bar that it's set for the last eight years in baseball simulation.

MLB 14: The Show on PlayStation 4 is certainly the version you’ll want if you’re a hardcore baseball fan. It’s achingly pretty (with only a few minor drawbacks), it sounds great, and the gameplay is top-notch.

MLB 14: The Show on the PlayStation 4 is about the looks. This is the same franchise as you know it with a next-gen coat of paint, and it looks incredible. Thankfully, it still plays wonderfully too, in large part to the same slick controls and gameplay features we’ve come to know and love.
Player detail is also taken to the next level, with renders that make the players easily recognizable not only by looking at their face, but by looking at their animations as well.

Coming into the release of MLB 14: The Show, it was clear that this is the king of baseball games. Not only is it the king but no other game is coming anywhere near it’s level of greatness for quite some time.

I wouldn't say that you're missing out if you play it on PS3, as both share the same content (even the same problems in the online component), but the PlayStation 4 version is a slight step up. The visual upgrades do come with a slight price, however. Load times are significantly longer on PS4.

MLB 14 The Show is a great baseball game marred by long load times, inconsistent online play, and performance issues. It's still a fun game and Road to the Show is, as usual, a great way to play the game. Fans of baseball will enjoy the game, but it's a little disappointing to see the performance issues.
Overall, even with its faults, it's hard not to still absolutely love MLB 14 the Show, especially on the PS4.
It's a game in danger of tossing away its decade-long undefeated streak. [July 2014, p.85]

While there are certainly some issues holding MLB 14: The Show back from being a classic in the sport game genre, there’s far more good than bad. The attention to detail, the plethora of content and the rock-solid gameplay make up for any problems.
A big hitter, but not quite a home run due to unfixed bugs and a lack of evolution. [June 2014, p76]

Sony’s MLB franchise has unquestionably made a successful leap to PlayStation 4. The franchise has never looked better and the game has made yet another jump into the realm of ‘true to life’. MLB: The Show retains its crown as the undisputed king of baseball games. This being said, it remains by in the large the same game we have played over the course of the past few years and the glitches do seem more prevalent.
MLB 14: The Show was a great game a month ago when it came out on PlayStation 3, and it remains so on PlayStation 4.

The transition to PS4 proved to be a healthy one for MLB 14: The Show. Continued online issues and increased load times aside, the visual boost provided by Sony's new hardware adds to what is already a solid baseball sim, making it the best version of the game available.

It’s easy to recommend to anyone who’s enjoyed the series before. It’s very easy to recommend to a baseball fan who has a PlayStation 4 and never played The Show before. I just hope that next year’s edition wows me a bit more.

The Show was clearly on its last legs on the PS3, and the revamped, more true-to-life ballparks infuse some much-needed atmosphere in the series’ PS4 debut. Meanwhile, Road to the Show includes several tweaks that help you create a more dominating prospect. Unfortunately, the player models don’t receive the same level of care, and the game’s online components aren’t on the level of most other sports franchises—issues that absolutely must be addressed going forward.

I don't quite understand why everyone is raving about the graphics in this game. Perhaps it's because the last mlb the show game I owned was 09, but I expected far better visuals in this game. I wouldn't say they are bad, I would just say they are unimpressive. It is a marginal step up from 09. Gameplay is fun, but background textures seem rushed, and without much thought or effort. Players still have the same dead eyes, awkward movements, rigid expressions and hair, and lifeless presentation. I may be wrong, but it seems clear to me that this game was made for ps3 and simply ported to ps4. With the ridiculous load times on ps4, and the marginal upgrades from ps3 version, I would say buy the ps3 version this time around, and wait until they actually make a game specifically for ps4 if you really want to be impressed. Hopefully they actually make use of the power and graphic capabilities of the ps4 next time around.

The graphics are eyepopping on a 1080p tv! The whole presentation is really authetic and gives you the feel of a tv broadcast. Road to the show is more addictive than ever with the quick counts added this year. Games take far less time to get through and never seem to lag when using this feature. Everything is very polished and online franchise mode is all kinds of fun to play with friends. My only complaint is the trophies system does not reward you for road to the show play or online dynasty specifically, instead focusing on player specific achievements.
The game is amazing all around its a must buy. with the ps4 the graphics are amazing. I think its the best sports game series out there. Its way better then 2k.

I didn't really know what to expect graphically because some of the Dev. Diaries and YouTube gameplay videos made the game look much better than the PS3 version, but others made it look only marginally better. Well, I can definately say that it looks incredible. Just like all the screenshots. Very, very impressive. And, due to the clarity and detail it's much easier to just even see the ball. Everything has a very thick look to it. Must be all the polygons. Play the PS4 version for a while then play the PS3 version for a while (if you have it). You'll be amazed. Other than that, also the gameplay seems a bit smoother. More fluid. What people are saying about long load times and infrequent frame rate issues is true though. The load times aren't nearly as long as some people seem to be making it though. Not from what I've experienced anyway. They are technically "long" though. And, the frame rate issues don't really effect the gameplay itself. It just happens once in a while in a replay or something. Not during the actual action of the game though. Again, from what I've experienced. I haven't played online yet but I have heard there are issues with that.

Best Baseball game to date! The 1080p display makes everything look more realistic whether it be the player models,fans or the attention to detail for each stadium. I would say for anyone who owns a PS4 and is a fan of Baseball this game is a must buy!

The first mlb 14 the show on the ps4 is good, but it does honestly feel rushed to some extent. The graphics are prettier and you'll notice it with better looking stadiums/ fans/ and the grass/dirt. New fielding/swing animations were a plus on the ps4 side. The downside, and this was really disapointing was the online. Half the time you can't even see the play while running the bases on offense, resulting on frustrating outs, gamechanger on close games.. It is bearable if you plan to play it casually, but if you plan to buy this game based on online alone, wait for a price drop if anything. The load times are long, but to me is bearable; but noticably worst than past iterations of the show. RTTS is very addicting and very reccomended game mode in the game. Overall a solid 85 from me, because it's still the best baseball sim, and if not for the laggy online; a must buy for baseball fans, especially on the ps4.

MLB 14: The Show looks and sounds amazing, adds some new features to its Road to the Show mode and allows for an excellent Baseball experience.  It falls to address its long loading times and lack of innovation in other areas such as it's terrible online connection.  Overall, an excellent baseball game, but still could use time in the minors.

Will not buy again until the RUNNING GAME is updated. I'm surprised that I can't find others criticizing this aspect of the game. It's PATHETIC!!. Please give us the ability to move freely. The way it is now your lead is limited to "fixed increments". If you take a one increment lead from 1st base they almost always throw over to try to pick you off (and are almost always successful - at 1st base). Most annoying is in certain situations if you take a one increment lead from 2nd they try over and over to pick you off even when they don't come close. For five minutes straight they were trying to pick me off so finally I had to take no lead. GARBAGE! Also I keep getting called out on steals where I am clearly safe. PATHETIC! I give this game a 3 overall since you spend most of your time running and that aspect of the game SUX!! Other bugs especially during sim. So many times I've seen a guy at 3rd that doesn't score on a double. This game is not worthy of the PS4.

I am a die hard baseball fan and played in high school and college, so I probably am biased, but the lighting and the textures, are top notch. The players faces and stadiums are incredibly detailed. Even though I love baseball and all previous installations of The Show, I am still pretty bad at hitting but that doesn't stop me from enjoying the game. Sliders make it more fun and less of a chore if you're looking to just unwind and play a game. The online is a little laggy, but I personally don't like playing online. The RTTS added a great new twist and makes you get drafted first by playing in a showcase. Great game and a MUST BUY for anyone who loves baseball!

I've played 5 diamond dynasty games so far and 3 of them we're cut short because an error occurred.  The menus in the online modes are painfully slow.  Swapping a pitcher from reserve to active took over 2 minutes.  It should take 0 minutes.  I'm plugged in direct to the router at 50mbps so I wouldn't think it's my internet. Why would anyone rate this below a 4? XBOX fanbois that don't get a baseball game that's who. The game is great, looks great and plays great. Nothing more I can ask for this year, thanks for giving us a baseball game.

Unless higher-resolution crowds or beards mean that much to you, stick with MLB on PS3 this season for the same price. MLB on PS4 is visually choppy, disturbingly slow, and doesn't offer much of anything short of "graphics" updates from the PS3 version. The loading times are practically eternal and gameplay feels exactly the same as before. I found the visuals to be no more enticing or particularly mind-blowing compared to PS3 anyway. I do like how SSD took the time to bring some updates into the franchise mode (the only mode I really play), but sadly they are only incorporated into a broken and confusing "online" franchise I have no desire to play.  I do love baseball and The Show, don't get me wrong, but if you only pretty much sim franchises or RTTS's like me, save yourself some considerable time and just stick with MLB 14 on PS3. I personally bought my PS4 at launch in anticipation for this game, and have since felt greatly underwhelmed. At least Watch Dogs is finally coming out soon!

MLB 14: The Show is a next-gen leap that I have never seen before. While many sports games, like Madden, NBA 2k, and Fifa all need a year or two to get back to the status their game once held on previous gen consoles, The Show didn't need a recovery period. Each sports game has its issues. Madden and FIfa didn't improve their games' graphics enough, NBA 2k minimized some of the game modes in order to get those beautiful visuals, and NBA Live, well, just sucked. MLB 14: the Show does not cut corners either visually or in content. The Show has always been the best looking sports game franchise, and this year is no different. The Show improves on already stunning visuals on the PS3 version and the graphics can be so lifelike, if you look about 10 ft. away from the TV, nine times out of ten, you would think you're watching a live MLB broadcast. Not only are the visuals improved greatly, but the gameplay seems a lot more refined than before. MLB 14 has ALL the game modes of the previous games and, surprisingly enough, the online seems quite improved in comparison to previous games. The only complaint I have about the game is the painfully long loading times, but for a game like this, it's worth waiting the extra 30 seconds. Overall, MLB 14: the Show for PS4 could possibly be the best baseball game of all-time. I have never been more impressed in my life with a game like this.

This series is the reason I bought a PS3 back in the day, and it's the reason I just purchased my PS4 this past weekend. I will mention that there is not much in the way of differences between 13 and 14, but even the devs admitted they haven't even begun to tap the potential of the PS4. That being said, it's still a gorgeous game and the small tweaks to RTTS have made it all the more fun to play.
Not as good as last year's, but still plenty entertaining and a must-own for baseball fans. Just wish they would eventually bring back all the old stadiums to use.

Immersive gameplay and very nice graphic. Like all games, some weird things happens, like people merging. Do not meter, The Show is really impressive. Once I heard, Baseball is a poker game with bat and ball. I can feel this feeling playing this game.

Most over-rated sports game ever. It can be fun to play for a while, once you get used to the clunky menu system, but as a long term baseball simulation it leaves a lot to be desired: Repetitive commentary and animations; CPU buggering your control of 40-man roster and September call ups; incorrect implementation of option years; wacky sim stats over several season; lack of stat tracking; weird FA signing logic where players leave 10s of millions on the table; incomplete minors; almost no real prospects included. Lots of people love the Road to the Show mode, but that's arcade, not a multi-season simulation of baseball.
I bought a ps4 just for this game. It hasn't disappointed. Everyone wants to complain about load times, but really who cares. Doesn't load during games and isn't glitchy. Fair trade
Look, just save you the time of reading these reviews and hurry up and buy this edition of MLB the show14, if you like baseball you will love this its amazingly that SIMPLE.

MLB The Show 14 is stunning! Is there room for graphical improvement? Sure. But that's to be expected on the first go around with a new console. What has me blown away is the attention to detail. Ballboys fielding foul balls. Fans walking the isles of the stadium. During gameplay I haven't once noticed the same fan rendered twice on screen. So many different fan models that the stadiums jump to life. New stadiums are beautiful. Player animations are nearly flawless as they have been for years in the MLB The Show series. Another new feature that I have found very useful is the advanced counts (which is optional). This allows each at bat to begin with an advanced count such as 2-1 or 3-2. This allows a full nine inning game to be played in less than half the time of classic gameplay. The advanced count feature is perfect for those who enjoy playing through full 162 game seasons. One improvement that I hope to see in future iterations would be better accuracy on some of the player faces. They don't look horrible by any stretch of the imagination but they quite reach the bar that was set by the NBA 2K series. Another improvement would be the texture detail of the stadium backdrops such as the city landscapes.

This is my first MLB experience, but I do have to say that the game seems like a lot of fun. The graphics are nice and the game-play is great. For me it seems like you really get in touch with baseball :)
Graphics wise, pleasing. time was put into this as anyone can tell
This is one of the best sports game there is. Fantastic graphics and gameplay. It offers a lot of different style of controls to pitch, catch, hit etc. which makes the game personalized to you.

I went to see my first baseball game when I was in America last year. I enjoyed and when I saw this come out I thought I would give it a go. I am very impressed with it, I feel it really captures the atmosphere and feel of a baseball game. The controls are very easy to pick up and the graphics just blow you away.

This is the first baseball game I've played since the old Ken Griffey Jr. games on the N64. I am decent fan of baseball and I was pleasantly surprised by how good this game is. It's in depth and has a really great presentation  with its partnership with MLB network, getting their commentators in for each game. I have alot of fun with the game and the varying level of difficulty that's involved with each factor of the game (pitching, hitting, etc.) are handled very well for each difficulty level. I do feel like they take away too much control at the beginner level though.

As a non-baseball fan it's odd that I was drawn to this game, however from the rave reviews and the amazing look, I couldn't resist. Not knowing the rules of baseball is a definite drawback, especially as there isn't really a tutorial, the game assumes you know what is going on, and how the mechanics work. After a little trial and error, I have basically got to grips with it, but it could do with some more pointers to help out with non players of the series. The graphics look incredible and the atmosphere whilst playing is excellent. There are tons of options to play with however downloading the squads cannot be done as an automatic download which can be irritating, the same for the initial install.The game will install from the home menu, however there is another massive install that has to be done in game, and blocks you from playing anything until it is complete.

Once your playing with your friends on a online franchise your going to learn to love this game.  The RTTS mode is fun and online franchise can be amazing.  I can say this GAMEPLAY rocks but the other aspects such as building stadiums, moving teams, general ownership options and uniform changes team name changes all non existent.. So yeah its the opposite to madden where the game sucks but the franchise mode is fairly deep.

Took me less then 2 hours for the download, and great game so far. If you're a MLB fan this definitely is for you. The single play is fun, but multi player is a little frustrating and lacking at time. Other then that 8-10
The game is amazing all around its a must buy. with the ps4 the graphics are amazing. I think its the best sports game series out there. Its way better then 2k.

I bought the ps3 in 2012 just to play MLB The Show after hearing how epic it was. When I got my hands on 2012, I wasn't disappointed.. 2013 even better and I probably played that game more then any other game ever.. Now that I've put in hours upon hours and am already at the max XP level of 30, I can say by far this is the most complete Show ever created. The graphics are great, the gameplay is fun and addicting, and the MP is better this year even if thats the only reason I didn't give it a 10.. There is still some major issues with online play, but it works good enough that I can play game after game without hating it. If you love baseball and sports, you can't miss out on this game!
MLB 14: The Show is a fun, albeit flawed experience. The game is fun, yet quite glitchy. Numerous crashes have occurred, unfortunately. That being said, the game is still a blast.

Definitely the best baseball game. Wish some more new things were introduced but for the first installation on the ps4. Gameplay has always been good, with some minor problems. Graphics are amazing and as a die hard baseball fan i really enjoy this game. Online has its problems but i dont play online so that doesnt upset me as much as others. If you hate the game because of the slow online features as such, fair enough but the offline is good.

Amazing game, the only reason I didn't rate it higher was because it is the first next gen title for the series it had a "port like" feel. I've been playing the series since '09 and this is easily the best one yet. Graphics are beautiful and the game play is on point...with a few minor animation glitches. Definitely a must buy for PS4 owners who enjoy simulation style sports gaming.

One of the best sports games i have ever played. By far the best sports game of the year 2014(Madden 15,NHL 15,NBA 2k15 etc..). MLB the show 14 is a game that will keep you coming back for more even months after you buy it!

9.0 max My first time on MLB 14 for PS4. Great game design and the improvements make game play smooth with good in game commentary. I especially like the HUD for multiplayer allowing  gamers to submit and play challenges with weekly and daily rewards. Practice and tutorials are also good so that you can improve skill with playing against your friends. Very clean layout, easy to learn, and addictive.

Graphics are top notch, Quick Counts is a God send, and both Franchise & RTTS modes are excellent. My only problem with the game & it's presentation is the commentary can get very repetitive, very quickly. Looking forward to MLB The Show '15.

Great baseball game. The graphics are very good and the gameplay is as well. The player ratings could be better though, and the outfielders seem to make every difficult play, and then miss a lot of simple ones, but it's not big deal. Overall, if you like baseball you'll like this game......
Never ever get this game. This is the worst video game I have ever played. This game glitches all of the time it sucks the players are in accurately rated and all this game does is cause stress.

Let's all agree that we're adults here, and admit that no company is ever going to break the mold or smash the glass ceiling in a sports genre.  To negatively review a game for being similar to its predecessors is unfair and ignorant.  This is a really fun game - dynamic considerations such as pitcher confidence and fatigue, hot/cold spots for a batter, a stat for clutch performance - which adds just enough human element to make it better than a simulation of the big leagues.

title: MLB 15: The Show
summary: With the addition of General Manager Contracts, you now must consider Ownership Expectations when operating your team, and your performance will determine the job offers that you'll be confronted with. Building a championship-caliber team is more dynamic than in previous iterations, with the new Performance-based Player Progression, as well as improved Trade and Contract logic. Partner up with Brand Sponsors, giving your broadcast elements an official sponsor and earn some extra cash to spend on your team.
reviews: Sony San Diego eschewed developing splashy back-of-the-box bullet points in favor of refining an already great game, exhibiting a confidence that is itself quietly remarkable — just like this series' consistency.
That small gripe aside, MLB The Show 15 is an excellent game and the franchise still rivals FIFA and Madden for the best sports simulation game.

MLB 15 The Show takes the field with equipment, experience, and an improved network. All in all, gamers are bequeathed with a finished product that’s, universal, immersive, and also accompanied by a one-of-a-kind Diamond Dynasty mode that will certainly inspire game modes from now on.
The new and improved game modes make this year's installment of The Show a grand slam for any sports fan.
It's still terribly hard for newcomers, but if you like baseball, this is the place to be.

MLB 15: The Show is the best baseball game ever made. But we have said that before about its predecessors. Sony San Diego has been doing so well, it is hard to top their own games. We specifically love the upgrade in the graphics and the online modes that have improved greatly.
People looking for drastic changes to Road to The Show or Franchise mode, however, may be disappointed with this PlayStation-exclusive baseball sim.

Let’s be honest here, many of you are going to upgrade every year regardless of what is added or changed. For those of you that look for major changes before jumping on board, I do think this year’s changes on PS4/PS3 are well worth the purchase.

Other than functional online play, there’s nothing revolutionary about this year’s version. It does get to legitimately say that it looks and plays better than any other baseball game you can buy right now, but only slightly.
You might not feel blown away by The Show 15 with anything new, but you’ll be blown away once more by everything that this series has done right for so long.

MLB 15: The Show has enough subtle additions to gameplay and graphics to keep returning fans satisfied. Online issues have been addressed, there’s more customization and control than ever before, and the addition of legends will please baseball purists. Even if you’re a newcomer this season, look no further than this year’s solid entry in the storied franchise.

Spring is in the air. After the mishap of MLB 14: The Show on current-gen consoles, MLB 15 steals the show making it the definitive baseball experience, one that will cater to both: stat-hungry fans and casual players.

The upgrades and improvements are there but a lot the game still feels underwhelming, simply due to its age. Even so, it’s impossible not to recommend this game to baseball lovers, as the purity and authenticity of the mechanics and physics, engrossing Road to the Show Mode, and unrestrained depth can keep you entertained for many months.

For someone playing the series for the first time the commentary will sound pretty good. However those who do so year after year are sick and tired of hearing the same things and not having the emotion from the announcers to match the big moments. It's well past time for SCEA to make a change in this area.
With enough updates to keep you going for the next year, superb graphics and the ability to import your saves from the previous versions, The Show 15 probably is the best baseball game out there.
Its total dominance over all contemporaries is beginning to feel routine. [June 2015, p.90]
The only option for baseball lovers. Despite its lack of new features a great game.

It's the under-the-hood gameplay improvements and additions that really make the difference, then; engaging in mental battles with base runners, pitchers, and even outfielders is a big part of the experience this time out. As a result, this is the best entry in a franchise that's showing no signs of slowing down – even after ten years of success.

MLB 15: The Show is an excellent recreation of the real baseball. There aren’t any groundbreaking new features that distinguish it from last year’s MLB 14, but some adjustments and some significant minor additions.

If you like the sport, this is a game that should be in your collection. Everything we like about baseball is included in it, with fan service in every corner. A technical game is always welcome, since it makes the fans to get excited as if they were dealing with the real sport.
MLB 15: The Show doesn’t bring any major additions to the table, but it does respectably tweak the most beloved modes to streamline the experience for pros and casuals alike.

As a baseball simulator, MLB 15: The Show delivers on almost every front, and it would be unfair to penalize the game for being too good, for too long. However, a good review score doesn’t necessarily mean that the latest edition is worth $60, especially to players who bought last year’s version.
It's still a hell of a game, but if you come back to it year in and year out, this season's offering doesn't have much of a spark.

While series like Madden struggle to create a worthwhile product year after year, The Show is fortunate in the sense that it has crafted a nearly-perfect baseball experience for several years. This year is no different and while that may not be everyone's cup of tea, the subtle improvements made to each new iteration is good news for baseball fans.

A topflight baseball video game, and in an era when we see far too many sports titles (and too many Maddens) that feel like roster updates, MLB 15: The Show manages to stay the same and be an improvement all at once.
The Show is still the best game in town, but that doesn't mean this year is the best it's ever been.
While still a fun and accurate depiction of America's pastime, MLB 15: The Show does little to move the franchise forward, and is hampered by the same recurring online issues.

This slow-and-steady approach to game design makes each iteration of the game comfortable, but it also makes for fantastic baseball sims that you can always count on, and that are always improving in subtle ways. In gaming, in baseball, and in life, that’s rare and valuable, even if it does make for a predictable rite of spring.

This new episode still is a great baseball simulator, but we think fans deserve a truly relevant step forward. If you own MLB 14, you should think twice, but if you don't and you like baseball, you won't find anything better.
The Show doesn't bring a lot of really impressive upgrades to the table, but that doesn't change the fact that it's still a really good baseball sim.

MLB 15: The Show smoothes out some issues that MLB 14 had last year. The graphical portion of the game is the biggest improvement with MLB 15 and something you’ll see right from the start. In addition to visuals, the game’s upgrades and additions in its modes, as well as some unexpected elements, make it a much better experience than last year’s title.

It simply looks and plays better than any baseball game ever has. That doesn’t hide the fact that the game also fails to innovate off the field in any material way. While that’s not a fatal flaw, there will come a time in the near future when its fans will demand new and interesting ways to enjoy its beauty.

The hardcore MLB: The Show faithful will welcome all the small incremental changes but the rest of us may be better served to wait another year to see what the team at SCEA San Diego can do to combat some of that franchise fatigue.

Baseball simulation became even better but I still think it’s not the best sport to turn into a video game. There are just too many nuances – how you grip the bat, how your wrist works etc. – that are impossible to recreate. [07/2015, p.61]

MLB 15: The Show is remarkable in that it adheres to a method of gameplay that's absent in most sports games. By privileging patience, attention to detail, and creating a system that rewards minor adjustments to the way we play (not unlike strategy adjustments in the real life MLB), MLB 15: The Show remains one of the only sports games on the market that not only has a distinctive and engaging look and feel, but also pushes an admirable ideology that, however subtly, explores how we engage with sports and videogames.

Because there's such a massive disconnect in quality between the online and offline versions of MLB 15: The Show, I'm really not sure how I feel about it. The former is absolutely awful, so bad that if I weren't a massive baseball fan already it would make me question how anyone could possibly like the sport.
There are one or two minor additions that are enjoyable, but the Diamond Dynasty continues to bore despite its overhaul.

It’s not a great option for those that already invested in MLB 14: The Show, in fact I probably wouldn’t recommend the upgrade. However if you’re new to the PS4 and want to enjoy a little of America’s past time this is one of the best sports games available on the PS4 today.

MLB 15 The Show is still good by virtue of the systems laid down over the last decade, but it has no ambition. Produced on third base thinking it hit a triple, it wouldn't even bother running in a sac fly.

Sony San Diego’s hardball sim only sees incremental changes this year, but several of them—particularly directional hitting—are welcome. The core game remains solid and even spectacular in places, but online remains a total joke.
MLB 15: The Show is the most accurate representation of the sport yet again, but feels more like a roster update than anything else, outside of a few improvements here and there.
MLB 15 The Show is a very immersive and exciting baseball experience that doesn't offer real improvements compared to last year's edition.
It’s weird when you feel so unenthusiastic about a game that you know is “good.” This used to be a series that I would never miss. These days, I’d probably take a long break from The Show if I could.

This game is way more amazing then the reviewers in general are giving it credit for. The most impressive aspect is not the graphics or the immersive feel of the game, but is the way that when you think like a batter, or like a pitcher, the game responds realistically. When you get a foul off late on a secondary pitch, then throw a fastball, it's a satisfying strikeout. As well as this, pitchers will follow real to life pitch selection and locations of those same pitchers against those same batters. You will also see at bats change over the course of the game. if you have a base knock on that pitcher's fastball, expect to see his secondary pitches next time. Not to mention reading body language for runners stealing and the best 'be a pro' mode in all of sports games in general! The complete package.

Partner up with Brand Sponsors, giving your broadcast elements an official sponsor and earn some extra cash to spend on your team.

MLB the show was generally a good game.  It was better than I expected, and was probably as close as you can get to a realistic baseball game.  It is challenging, and it is worth the buy if you are a baseball fan.  If you are not a baseball fan, I'd advise you don't make the purchase.  My player, franchise, and UT are all easy to navigate through.  Pretty simple, pretty fun, hope this review helps.

MLB 15: The Show is by far the best baseball game that has been out in awhile. In my opinion as far as gameplay goes it is easily the most realistic of all the MLB the show games. One thing that really stands out to me as to why the game has such a realistic gameplay is the hitting aspect. In past MLB games most people just used X to swing regular and maybe square to power swing with a big power hitter. In this version they have came up with three different approaches to hitting, regular, power, and contact swing. Being able to choose and execute use these three really makes it feel like real life situations and having more control where you hit the ball regardless to the pitch location. The other realist difference maker is the drag bunting. As I'm an advocate for some small ball being played in previous games the drag bunt wasn't very realistic. It was almost impossible to successfully execute a drag bunt down the first base line or to the second baseman even with the fastest players in the league. With the new gameplay a lefty can place a drag bunt past the pitcher and towards the second baseman for a base hit which is what the games best bunters do.

Another fantastic rendition of MLB. The game is finally beginning to look like a next gen title with updated graphics, physics etc. The loading times are VASTLY improved which makes a huge difference if you play RTTS. There are still legacy issues like no closed dome options, sloppy uniform details etc but if you love baseball you can go no wrong with this.
MLB 15: The Show is a great game with a big problem. The game is a blast to play and very addictive. However, there are so many glitches that it almost takes away from the experience.

title: MLB The Show 16
summary: ShowTime takes critical in-game Road To The Show moments and slows them down to give you maximum control. Make Gold Glove plays and come through in the clutch with this tool that allows finer, more focused user control. Immersive Road To The Show – With a curated in-game environment and a revamped training system that includes Gameplay Perks, The Show 16 offers a more personalized experience that acknowledges key moments of your career as you travel from a nobody to the Hall of Fame. An improved “Topps Prospect Showcase” includes Bowman Scout Day and a new 20-80 scale scouting report. Streamlined game logic maximizes the time spent in situations that matter. Conquest Mode – This single-player online experience takes your Diamond Dynasty team on the road as you travel through North America en route to becoming America's most popular team. As you earn fans, strategically move them to hold territories or help take over new territories as you attempt to achieve baseball manifest destiny.
reviews: Previous versions were too buggy to be worth checking out unless you couldn't live without baseball on your home console; this time, they got it right, with an entry in The Show series that reminds you of just how impressive it can be.

The visuals and upgrade player models, beautiful broadcasting packages, improved game modes, and the epic homerun celebrations are just a few of the reason this game is truly awesome. There’s no better way to get amped up for the upcoming baseball season than with MLB The Show 16. This year’s version is worth every penny and will go down as the best baseball simulator ever created. It will hold you over until the Cubbies hoist the World Series trophy in October.
Another year, another outstanding sports title.

Simply put, MLB The Show 16 is the best baseball game available on any current-gen console. It looks, plays, and feels amazing, offering many ways to play the great American pastime. Franchise and Road to the Show modes have made incremental but impressive improvements, while Diamond Dynasty offers entirely new ways to play. Not every mode works, but it’s encouraging to see such a radical new mix of gameplay.
You need to know the sport to master it - hence no 10/10 this year - but PS3's greatest sports series is on the verge of once more dominating all contemporaries. [June 2016, p.94]
Sony San Diego continues to raise the bar with MLB 16: The Show, finding an almost perfect balance between innovation and tradition.
MLB: The Show 16 is one of the best baseball games I have ever played. Granted, I haven’t played many in my life, but this one really does have some great things going for it.

One of the best sports games you’ll ever play. I haven’t seen fit to hand out a 9+ score for one of these titles since 2011, and I really thought last year’s entry wasn’t anything special. They’re all great games, don’t get me wrong, but this is the first installment of The Show that absolutely feels like a full, complete, and rewarding package that hits just about every sweet spot. A few of the minor flaws franchise followers will recognize still linger, but the overall experience is nigh-on unparalleled. Like I said at the start: It’s all about feeling like you’re there, that you’re actually trying to master this very complex sport. And when everything seems to gel, seems to fit, seems to reflect reality…well, should we nitpick and complain? No, just rejoice!

While the gameplay is similar to years past, the new modes add a ton of previously unfound variety. The Road to the Show mode has finally been updated and is guaranteed to hook longtime players. On top of that, Diamond Dynasty no longer feels like an afterthought, and is instead one of the most joyous things about the game. After a slip and fall last year, Sony has managed to make sure MLB The Show 16 lands directly on its feet.

PS4’s biggest sports exclusive delivers a moonshot home run, thanks to perfectly balanced fundamentals, astonishingly lifelike presentation, and little details that few rivals – past or present – have come close to getting right.

While last year's release felt like the series was plateauing, this year, MLB The Show 16 returns better than ever. The gameplay remains consistently solid, and tweaks and additions to Road to the Show and Diamond Dynasty will surely keep people coming back for more.

While last year’s game may have been really one of the first outings for the series that felt like little more than a roster update, the series has truly returned to form once again this year with MLB The Show 16.

San Diego Studio continues to show love for baseball with MLB 16 The Show, taking its historic limelight and bringing to it a multitude of new options, features, and enhancements. Every annual release should be better than the last year, but MLB 16 The Show expands on all fronts with dividends and adds even more reasons to crack the bat.

As usual, MLB The Show remains the series to beat in the baseball simulation category (not that there’s much competition). Unlike last year, which served mostly as a spit-shine to a venerable series, MLB The Show 16 features meaningful upgrades, including a few new modes to change up the way baseball is played.

Another year and another good outing for SCE San Diego Studio. MLB The Show 16 has some great improvements for Road to the Show, but some problems still persist. Baseball lovers will definitely enjoy the game.

It is nice to see that the team over at Sony San Diego has been given enough rope to try new things. The resulting product has once again shown why the MLB: The Show series is still one of the best sport simulations in the industry.

The enhancements and upgrades are significant making this one of the deepest baseball games I have ever played. The hardcore MLB The Show faithful will be all in regardless, but if you have taken a few years off from the franchise, now is the time to jump back in.

Last year, The Show failed to deliver the right amount of additions to the series, but this year we've been overwhelmed by how many things San Diego Studio is bringing. Again, the best game for baseball fans.
MLB The Show 16 is a letter of love for all baseball fans and fore those who likes sports games. Outstanding visuals, great game modes and accurate controls, makes this game a great experience.
MLB The Show 16 is simply the best modern game of baseball. Despite being quite similar to 2015, it adds improvements and additions that makes it not look like a clone of the last edition.
The new bells n’ whistles don’t add much, but when something this good ain’t broke why fix it?

The Show looks good, plays great and is deep enough to overshadow moderately unbalanced visuals and a slight void of personality. If you’ve always loved the series, the fire will still burn despite the minor infractions.
Simply put, if you want a baseball video game, this is the game you must play - even if you have to get a Playstation 4 just to play it.
MLB 16 The Show improves in many ways it needed to, but don't expect it to feel like a totally new game.
The Show 16 remains a reference among classic sports simulations. More attractive, richer, more immersive, this game is offering many ways to play the league.
MLB The Show 16's additions and changes may not be breakthroughs, but they refine weaker areas of the game that had been routine or even chorelike.

Once you deduce how to use the multifarious forms of interactivity, The Show is wonderfully calming when the rhythm of pitching becomes zen-like. As the controller beats like a frantic heart when the bases are loaded, the physiological feeling of vibration sends you inside yourself. But the experience as a whole isn’t completely fulfilling. The immediate challenge that remains is something as old as the hills — tiresome storytellers (the announcers). In an era during which we feel we don’t have the time to sit still on the couch for even an hour, listening to them pontificate is a royal pain.

Yes, MLB: The Show 16 is more of the same in a lot of ways. However, new features like ShowTime and modes like Conquest give this entry enough new toys to feel like a meaningful improvement over last year’s entry. If you’re a fan of the series, this year’s version is worth checking out unless you’re suffering from the most severe of digital baseball boredom.
Whereas NBA 2K16 found a way to take a step back last year with additions that didn’t feel wholly meaningful, MLB The Show 16 is a shining example of exactly how to make a great game even better.
The series is moving away from being an authentic baseball simulation, but for longtime players of The Show, these pie-in-the-sky ideas are just what this baseball series needs.

MLB The Show 16 continues to find innovative ways to push the series forward by adding new features and improving on old ones. Some new problems have arisen, however, and old ones—most notably the horrendous stability of online play—continue to persist and hold the series back.

MLB The Show 16 is yet another excellent game in the series, but only enough has been done to sustain its status as such in coming off similarly received editions. Failing to properly address some long-running core deficiencies and a lack of innovation has prevented the franchise from reaching even greater heights...Instead, Sony San Diego has continued to build on its strengths with visuals and gameplay while further expanding the appeal of Diamond Dynasty. In doing so, The Show may lack some flash but it remains the most steady sports gaming franchise in existence today.

For better or worse, MLB The Show 16 focuses heavily on Diamond Dynasty this year. The on-field action is strong as ever, and the bullet time-like Showtime is interesting, but the bulk of the improvements are in Diamond Dynasty-centric additions like Captains and Battle Royale. If you're a curious newcomer who likes baseball, you will find an extremely strong baseball sim; but if you're a returning player, your mileage will probably vary depending on how willing you are to indulge in The Show's card-collecting mode.
While it’s hard to say it’s a grand slam, it’s definitely an incredibly well done baseball game.

If MLB The Show's new MO is just coasting on the good gameplay and providing minor tweaks to disparate modes, each with their own appeal (or lack thereof, depending), then there's no greater candidate for games-as-service that I can see. Because there's good money in it, however, I doubt we'll drop the yearly release format. It would at least be nice to cut the PS3 version, provided that the freed-up resources would make the yearly changes a little less incremental. Still, the baseball itself is as good as ever, and one of the better modes, Road to the Show, is far less clunky this time around.
MLB The Show 16 is yet another great game of baseball, but for the first time I felt like the franchise is starting to wane in its greatness.

Big on feature, major in community activity, and strong in replay ability, this year’s Show certainly has done well. For Sony, like EA’s Madden series, there are few to no challengers to the genre so success lies within their own hands. So the question is, if it ain’t broke, will they still try to fix it, or if it is broke, do they still care to fix it?

The game is a big step up from last years release.  There are two new modes for Diamond Dynasty users.  One is called conquest and allows users to play against the CPU to earn some of the best legends available in this year's release for their Diamond Dynasty Team.  The developers weren't stingy with rewards either.  Playing this mode allows users that prefer offline gameplay to earn some of the best legends in the game (among them Ichiro Suzuki and Tony Gwynn).  The animations are smoother and more realistic than last year.  There are animations and gameplay situations that could use smoother transitions to create more realistic gameplay but these do not detract at all from the single player experience at all.  Some of the still rigid and slow transitions in infield fielding and throws to the cutoff man are exploited in by some users in online gameplay.  One of the unique features that sets MLB The Show apart from other sports games is Sounds of the Show.  Sounds of the Show allow users to set walkup music, home run music and chants for each player in the MLB for a more realistic gameplay experience. The game allows you to import 511 mp3s from a USB into the game's jukebox.  This way when I play and feel like listening to music instead of the commentary, which is outstanding, I can listen to a shuffled playlist in game of an set of songs I choose.
Great game.  Big step up from MLB 15 in terms of animations and gameplay modes.  The gameplay is smoother and the game includes new modes that should keep you busy until MLB 17.

I've played a great deal of time between MLB The Show 14 and 15. I loved both of those games and this one is no different. I play it mostly for the Road to the Show mode and I've played about 3 months of games so far in my career. I REALLY like the additions they've made. The biggest turn off on the older games was when baserunning, it was WAY too hard to get back to the base in time. That was fixed by putting the game into slow-mo as the pitcher begins his move. If you don't react quickly you will get picked off but you don't have to be expecting to even have a chance like the old games. The slow-mo/reaction concept was put into fielding situations as well which I really like. There is also a new throwing mechanic they built it which makes throwing much more than just pushing a button. I am VERY impressed with the game so far and I'm excited to see what else it has to offer.
This is an excellent game. There has been marginal/massive overhauls to multiple different game modes. If you are not into diamond dynasty, it will change your opinion of the game.

Last year I criticized Sony San Diego Studio for taking away striding, when hitting, but I got used to it, and eventually didn't miss it much. This year, they brought it back and it was like welcoming back an old friend. This year, I started with Road to the Show, because I almost played that exclusively, the past few years, except for a short run at Diamond Dynasty, last year. I was disappointed to see manual catch was removed. This series used to be known for adding choices, but leaving what was already there, to personalize your experience. They've stopped doing that, now, and it's unfortunate the choice to use manual catch is no longer an option. Despite this small complaint, everything else just feels... right. From hitting to pitching to fielding... and i've primarily played Play Now games to build up Dynamic Difficulty. The new animations and the added commentary are much-welcomed additions. I'm sure Conquest Mode and Battle Royale will have me returning Diamond Dynasty, and the small hiccup of not having our rewards for preorders was taken care of with a post at facebook that directed customers what to do, if you hadn't received your entitlements. I've supported this franchise since its inception, and this year's version is the best yet, In other words... it's quite a catch, just not a manual one. It's automatic, this year. :)

This was my first experience with the show since 2012 and the game feels and plays great compared to the games of a few years back. I enjoy being able to speed through games at an arcade pace if I need to and play an authentic baseball experience if i have the time. There's a bunch of new game modes for me to explore that will keep me busy all season.

The guys at San Diego Studios have continued to make a great product with this year's installment. While lingering issues like long menu load times and some frame rate like to say hi, the gameplay is more dynamic than ever. They've added new modes and features that only make me want to keep playing day in and day out. Conquest mode and Battle Royale add to the already addictive Diamond Dynasty.

MLB The Show 16 has made minor changes that have made Road to the Show much more enjoyable. The frustration of playing one game and then having to wait 10 minutes (exaggerated) to go back to the menu to select the next game is gone. They have made it so that you can play multiple games without navigating away from the game screen. On top of that they allow you to use your training points without navigating back to the menu also. I'm still struggling to figure out how to take advantage of the slow motion, but I'm sure that will come with practice. I have not played Battle Royale or Conquest, but I look forward to trying those out as well. While the play style is very similar to last year that doesn't bother me. Also I am not about to get nearly as butthurt about wrong audio calls and I haven't seen substantial bug yet so I'm not go to go off like you-know-who. Hope you enjoy reading this massive paragraph.

As with every new edition of The Show, the stadium and presentation upgrades make the game worth buying for any baseball fan out there. The return of stride hitting bumps this rating up to an 8 for me. The load times are quite long and the face models are so bad that it takes away from what is otherwise a very beautiful and fluid game.
I took 3 years off The Show and I must say, it's good to be back. Stadiums look authentic, graphics are crisp, and gameplay is smooth. Starting my 162-game franchise today, wish me luck.

This is probably the most complete package version of the show since it's inception, period. The graphics are improved even more with the physics based rendering, the dynamic whether ( shadows creep in if you're playing a afternoon game), the super realistic plus over 100 new fielding animations makes the gameplay feel more authentic than ever before. The few added additions to franchise mode and rtts makes it even more addictive and enjoyable than ever before. And the new mode battle royale is like a dream come true for me ( I always wanted a fantasy draft team to play online against others). But what impressed me the most was the online, this online still stutters ever so often but the parity between offline and online has been the best this series has ever has. Not a perfect game, but this one is a no brainer for baseball fans/ people who enjoy this series.
5 Years since i bought a baseball game, this is a great game, you need about 2-3 innings to get a hold of the controls, it's easy and fun to play. graphics are awesome

I've own every single MLB XX:  The Show, and TBH, I was adamant about picking this game up since I felt that previous versions played the same year over year, but man was I wrong.  The game is not perfect but it feels so good on PS4, the camera angles, the way the ball travels off the bat and the fluid animations just make your jaw drop.  I'm a little concerned with a few players which faces look a little odd, but the lighting and gameplay just blows away last years version.  Love the addition of custom music and certain arcadey features that make the game less repetitive.  Conquest for me is a plus and no there is no import your face, create a stadium or relocation which is sad and are highly requested features but I guess we'll have to wait a bit for that.  The commentary has been vastly improved but still needs a little more work.  All in all MLB 16:  The Show is a masterpiece (considering the type of game it is), there is a lot of content to keep everyone busy for a long time. 9.5/10  The lack of hair options (i.e. using actual players hair styles), inability to put your face in the game, some actual players odd looking faces, a somewhat repetitive commentary, lack of creating a stadium and relocating option keeps this game from being a 10,  other than that this game is almost flawless.

Mlb the show 16 does it again with amazing baseball sim gameplay. The new additions in Diamond Dynasty are awesome from all the new flash back cards to battle royale! Gameplay is very smooth and even the online gameplay has become a ton less laggy. I just wish they improve conquest mode a little bit. Road to the show is as good as ever, I just can't put this game down.

I can't think of a single bad thing to say about The Show 16. If you love baseball, this is a no-brainer. No other baseball game is in the same league as this title. This year's game is a significant improvement over last year's mediocre release. The game is certainly in the big leagues and I would venture to say it rivals NBA2K as the best sports simulation in existence. EA can learn a lot here about how to make a proper sports title.

Another great entry in the series.  After a few patches, this may be the best The Show yet.  I am not sure where the other reviewers that state that this is the "same as last year" or "PS3" graphics are coming up with it.  A simple look at the game play videos and the fact sheet reveals that these statements are simply false.

The additions this year were more subtle to the average player, but really were instrumental for me actually buying this year's addition. Namely, the re implementation of your own music into every aspect of the game. There really isn't anything more satisfying than hitting a monster home run with your favorite song playing throughout the stadium. This was the biggest loss from transitioning from the ps3 to the ps4. And it took until this addition, finally, to be reintroduced. The second is the advanced statistics. There is absolutely nothing better than seeing WAR in the game. It warms my heart so to see my previous year's terrible -0.64 WAR along with a terrible BB% and K%. Really brings the reality of baseball to the game. Finally there is a reason to work for that walk to raise that OBP. Finally there is a stat that shows that no, it's your team's terrible defense not your pitching. The other new mode is quite fun but isn't nearly as significant as those two. Sure the release was rocky, but no game deserves to be rated based on its release alone.

this game is very good.. player model look good but face model look weird. Graphic is great especially stadium, Lighting look awesome. gameplay is great. it feel so smooth. hitting balls is so good.. MLB 17 really need improve player realistic face expression and likeness

A brief review of my impressions for this game is that I love it. It's a really great baseball simulator game that is so good I though I have to play the others. The gameplay is excellent and the graphics are also good. 10/10

The Show and NBA 2K franchises are the BEST sports games year in and year out. Both consistently improve upon the previous iteration with each new release. With updates to roster, graphics, lighting, character models, gameplay elements, etc., this is the best baseball game available. It's a must buy if you are a fan of baseball.

this game is amazing ever i playing.. visual is goregous, player model look great.. stadium look goregous, gameplay are excellent. Commentary and radio are great. keep up good work San diego studio with SCEA

Excellent game from SDS.  Definitely worth the purchase.  In spite of what other reviewers have written the servers are working fine after some minor problems at release (which SDS comped players with free stubs and packs).  I was very happy to upgrade from MLB 15 to 16.  Lots of new features and animations.  Plus Sounds of the Show is on PS4 so you can create playlists of your own mp3s in game!

I truly think any review higher then maybe a 7 for this game is a paid review. 10/10 is an utter joke with so many bugs in a game like this so do not trust any of those. Now for the game break down, there are plenty of good mixed with a ton of bad in this game so I will list the pros and cons of the game and let you judge.

This game is full of bugs and glitches and that makes it very unpleasant to play. Runners over 85 speed can basically just take 3rd base as they are next to impossible to stop from stealing. The base running controls are slow and cumbersome. I have had base runners run right by a fielder on the base path trying to tag them. Plays in diamond dynasty will sometimes show opposite results for plays(i.e. safe or out). etc etc etc. Imagine playing an hour long game and have it decided by such glitches. The graphics are good and the overall layout of franchise mode and diamond dynasty are good. The game play is just FAR from polished or smooth. Overall I am very disappointed in this game as I believe  game play should be better for a competitive sports game . Wish I did not buy digital copy.

Hitting and gameplay is overrated. The only good part is the pitching, but overall, this game was really a waste of money.  The fact that you have to hold down the button and if you dont, then it's a check swing. The game is kinda glitchy and you can barely control the player movements. Good graphics, but not good enough to change my opinion.
disappointed in MLB the gameplay is bad  the graphics look  like a PS3 game the game has alot of bugs dont buy this game save your money for a better game

Great gameplay with great graphics, but there are some BIG problems  The game is LOADED with bugs, the new radial graphs are impossible to read, diamond dynasty only works on occasion, the game is 10x slower than last year (I'm not exaggerating), among many more problems. Kind of disappointed.

If you play career mode do not buy this game,unless you like sitting on the bench your whole career.my created player has more home runs runs batted in and better fielding percentage and invited to play in the home run derby and play in the all star game but yet still miss have the season sitting on the bench.Whats wrong with this picture????? The fielding needs to be worked on have problems making double plays because short stop won't go to the base and pitcher at times won't cover 1st base...like I said if you like career mode the game isn't for you

Online franchise servers are a joke!!! Servers crash all the time and no information from the company.  I have a full league of members and everyone is fed up and has either sold their game by now or given up on the game. If you plan to buy for online franchise, do not buy and save you money.  This company is focused on one thing, stealing your money!!!!

Same **** as last year with the new rosters. If you have any other current gen The sho game dont bother. If you dont have a current gen The show game I would recomend that you buy The show 2014 or 2015 for a fraction of the price.

Wow have things changed from MLB 14: the Show.  I miss MVP baseball 2005 so bad.  MLB 16 features even more horribly complicated menus that sometimes take forever to load or freeze altogether.  There's like 1 thousand features i'm sure most people never ever use and the learning curve to figure out what exactly is going on is pretty ridiculous.

Great game.  But the servers are still totally broken after the game has been out for almost a month.  Some nights I have to wait an hour just a get any of the online features to work.  At this point Sony has stopped even acknowledging the game breaking server issues that plague their release.  Having watched their Twitch streams before the game was released I must say that I am thoroughly disappointed.  They claimed in their videos that the game when into testing a month before release.  It is mind boggling that they did not find that their game is full of bugs.  Also this company knows damn well how much server load to expect from pre orders.   The servers for this game are garbage.

This is the same game has last year.  The same animation problems with the catcher, pitcher being hit with the ball, and stealing is so easy.  Do not buy it.  Just play 15.  The new legends are not all in the game offline only in Diamond Dynasty mode.  Not worth the money you have to pay to play the new Draft Battle game mode it is not free.

The "good" reviews look planted, especially since they're all liked to raise them to the top.  You CANNOT be have a legitimate review of this game if you gave it a "10."  Every mode is broken.  I don't play online, but most people have "Challenge Failed" repeatedly.  Do some research on forums to see all the issues before you buy.

Heres a REAL review that was not paid for by sony, mlb 16 the show  is still graphically the same game it was the last 2 seasons on ps4. The commentary is recycled the player models still looked ripped from the ps3 and the jerseys still have no cloth physics.

Once again this game has great graphics and solid gameplay, however it's all brought down by how many bugs there are. Given that they release one of these every single year with some minor adjustments, I find it unacceptable that it has so many bugs and glitches. Avoid this one and buy an older one.

MLB The Show is an amazing franchise. They took my days of playing 2K on Xbox and redefined what a baseball game could be. The gameplay is awesome and can't be overstated. That said, this installment, unfortunately, has brought me somewhat back to reality. The buggy-ness and lack of attention to details was really disappointing. The removal of statistics in some of the modes too, or added difficulty in finding them , seemed very weird. Load times inside of the game and in some modes are ridiculous too.  The most frustrating thing about all of it was that these things are rookie mistakes, things that games who don't have the money and power to support them would have, not a proven, great quality studio.

love this game! its fun to play in all sorts of modes, and its fun to simulate, its even fun to just lay down and watch a game in bed... I wish though they would add every teams old stadiums as well, would be cool to play at torontos exhibition stadium, or a place like candle stick stadium..
Great baseball game. The story mode is a little bit lacking, with almost no reaction to anything other than playing the matches, but the gameplay is solid.

title: MLB The Show 17
summary: With expanded missions, exclusive rewards, and all new live content
reviews: Of course, if I'm being honest, offline single-player is what I care about most when it comes to MLB The Show anyway, so it's not like multiplayer was going to change my opinion too much one way or the other. And from that perspective — that is, as someone who's probably going to spend a few hundred hours with the game over the next year, with 95% of that being in RTTS — I have to say that MLB The Show 17 once again delivers.

Rather than shooting for the moon and burning up on the Sun, MLB The Show 17 calls out it’s home run and knocks a dinger over the left field wall like it was nothing. This game is truly a delight and a must have for anyone who enjoys baseball simulations, even if you are an Indians fan.

MLB The Show 17 builds on last year’s version, which many cited as the best in the series, by adding some key features and improvements. Most notable are increased hit variety, MLB Network integration, and the RTTS documentary. All of these additions make the game feel more like real baseball. This authenticity makes games more fun to play, as it’s easier than ever to become invested in every pitch.

While it’s still got room to grow, what’s here is great for fans of baseball. MLB The Show 17 is a clear step up from 2016 in gameplay, presentation, and overall experience. Some control and commentary quibbles remain, but not enough to detract from what is the best in the series to date, and one of the best baseball games today. As a PS4 exclusive, Xbox players should be envious.

To say I’m pleased with my return to the series after a brief hiatus is an understatement. This feels exactly like the Show I remember with some fantastic additions. The only thing that keeps it from getting higher marks are the online connectivity issues and some other small concerns (including some strange ball physics in the outfield that has led to a lot more ground rule doubles than seems realistic). If you’re a fan of the sport and you have a PlayStation 4 you have to buy this game. If you don’t, you’ll be missing out on a tremendous entry in this seminal series.

There’s no denying that MLB The Show 17 is one of the most comprehensive and realistic baseball simulators that has ever been made. No matter what sort of baseball experience you’re looking for, I can pretty much guarantee you’ll find it in the latest from San Diego Studios.
Gameplay, graphics, game modes: everything in MLB The Show 17 gets improved compared to last year. If you love baseball you'll have a lot of fun playing this game.
San Diego Studio keeps delivering with a game that's full of content, deeper and more accessible than ever, and with relevant additions. A must-have for any baseball fan.

MLB The Show 17 sets a new pinnacle for the franchise. It creates more depth for its tent pole modes and polishes everything else to a terrific gleam. Some online issues and glitches still continue to plague the series at launch, but you might get so engrossed in Franchise or RTTS that you won’t even notice until they’re fixed.

Overall MLB The Show 17 does what it’s supposed to do and builds on last year’s great game. It’s hard to truly improve year after year without any competition but the development team is able to do that with this game. The documentary style of RTTS is brilliant and the new MLB Network broadcast addition is great and adds authenticity to the game. MLB The Show 17 is a great game for any baseball fans and will provide a great experience from any of their game modes.

MLB The Show 17 is an ambitious game that tries to dazzle players with new avenues of play and a story, but is at its best on the field, where the action has never looked or played better. After slumping last year, Sony came back firing with an experience that feels new again, even if its foundation stretches back over a decade.

When not compared to previous iterations of the series, MLB The Show 17 is a great baseball game with something for everyone. The various modes provide players with a plethora of options both online and offline. When compared to previous MLB The Show games, MLB The Show 17 stands out as the best iteration of the series thus far, however, as a “game of failure,” there is room for improvement.

At first blush, MLB The Show 17 is more of the same; but when taken together, it's actually a great update. It brings with it a lot of small but much-needed tweaks to the play on the field, and the graphics have never looked so good. Even better, Franchise mode actually feels approachable now. It leaves some opportunities on the table, but MLB The Show is still a great baseball sim that feels that much better with this year's update.
The dynamic lighting, stadium details, and player designs are astounding. The gameplay can be punishingly realistic or a cartoony home run derby depending on how you customize your experience.

Sony has rarely struck out with their annual MLB The Show series and this year’s entry manages to keep that trend going.  With the worthwhile improvements to Road to the Show, Franchise Mode, and the incredibly fun addition in Retro Mode, San Diego Studio has knocked it out of the park with MLB The Show 17.

Baseball is a sport like no other. It looks to its past as much to its future. MLB The Show 17 embraces both. From an introductory video sticky-sweet with nostalgia, to various flashy quick-game options, short challenges, and custom controls. It is a game for fans of the past and present. A game that allows easy access for those who haven’t played a baseball game in a while. Or, even for those who have never played one before.

As I'm veering into my third All-Star Game with my created slugger, I think about how I'm putting the games typically in my wheelhouse — like another Sony creation, Horizon Zero Dawn — on the back burner to digitally partake in a game that I didn't think I enjoyed. Real-life baseball still has a long way to go to get my eyes on it more, but MLB The Show 17 is a pretty good place to start.

MLB The Show 17 is not a huge improvement over the previous chapter, but Sony San Diego managed to renovate the franchise, maximizing every single element of the game. Beautiful to see, even more beautiful to play. A must for every baseball fan.

I overlooked the franchise for too long, as I am glad that this year I ventured into the Major League ballparks. This is a mode-filled, very entertaining baseball experience that is not quite perfect yet, but nonetheless will eat your time away.

Changes in physics and AI make the game more realistic and enjoyable, but there are still some issues with AI player decision making that can detract from the final product. Road to the Show mode is still fun with a new documentary twist, but it's ultimately the same mode as last year. The Show 17 is a good title for baseball fans new and old, but don't expect anything mind blowing this time around.

MLB The Show 17 is another solid entry into an increasingly solid franchise. It slips a bit with the new additions like a tweaked Road to the Show and Critical Situations, but it succeeds in a silly, wholly enjoyable retro mode. But even with the negatives, the MLB The Show series is enjoyable enough to mask those bumps and bruises. MLB The Show 17 is another bullet-point in a historically successful sports franchise.
A joy to play, as ever - though we could've done without the clear-as-day influence of the PS3.

It's hard to think how Sony San Diego could improve this franchise inside the field, bragging with great animations and amazing IA behaviours, while there's still room to be better in some aspects of its great game modes, like lack of own identity in Road to the Show. Thanks to a great level of customization and difficulty, there's an MLB The Show 17 for every baseball fan.

If you are a diehard baseball simulation fan, you’ll feel right at home. If, however, you were looking for something with a little more simplicity and arcade-like control elements then MLB The Show 17 may be the time for you to give the series a try again. There are a lot of things both new and old to like with this year’s version, and I’m glad to be back to my wannabe-athleticism tendencies.

In a class by itself, San Diego Studios continues to wow audiences with an authentic baseball sim with its newly released MLB The Show 17. It’s visually astounding, and all games modes have that extra something to keep you playing long into the night with only a few significant things keeping it from statistical perfection.

After years of consistent quality, it almost goes without saying that MLB The Show 17 is a great game. The simulation makes several significant evolutionary steps forward, while still not losing sight of the genre’s storied past. Both newcomers and veterans will find something to appreciate in this year’s outing, along with a little bit of nostalgic appeal sprinkled throughout for good measure.
The Show is still striving for perfection, but if you love baseball and video games, you need this in your life.
MLB The Show 17 has changed and it has became an even better game. Well done.

MLB The Show 17 takes smart, calculated approaches to improving its gameplay while expanding the Road to the Show Mode with its addition of an ongoing narrative. In an attempt to solidify an excellent baseball simulation experience, one with more control over minute details in all available gameplay modes, the development team builds upon a solid base.

This is the biggest Show yet with a tremendous amount of options and ways to play. A few online hiccups and microtransactions hamper the overall package, but nearly every other aspect of The Show is wonderful. Whether you are a veteran of the franchise or a newcomer intrigued by baseball, MLB The Show 17 is a towering home run.

MLB The Show 17 is the only AAA baseball game in town, but the series is clearly not content resting on its laurels. With notable improvements in several areas and increased accessibility to try and hook newcomers, baseball fans should find a lot to like about this year's release. Play ball!
